Representative Leslie HerodFireside at Five was live.

Join Fireside at Five and The University of Denver for Chat 2 of The Future of Denver Series.

In continuation of our Equitable Development and The Future of De...nver Series, join Fireside at Five and the University of Denver as we dive back into the issues and opportunities surrounding equitable development in the city of Denver. 2020 has been a challenging year for everyone and as we push forward into a brighter future, we must ask how we can stimulate and support diverse small businesses, eliminate neighborhood insecurities, push back on systemic limitations for growth, and holistically address the needs of all our community members. We look forward to tackling these issues and discussing Denver’s infinite potential on this upcoming Fireside Chat. Whether you’re a big thinker, local beer drinker, or you just want to see people on I-25 using their blinkers -- register for the live-stream and get ready for some great discussion!

Panelists:
Kara Penn - Owner & Principal Consultant of Mission Spark

Representative Leslie Herod - Colorado House of Representatives, House District 8

Mark Shaker - Founder of Stanley Marketplace and Broadway Market

Rob Smith - CEO of Rocky Mountain MicroFinance Institute

Dr. Tom Romero - Interim Vice Chancellor for the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at The University of Denver

item.title: “The system is especially attractive in the coronavirus era,...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The system is especially attractive in the coronavirus era, where voting at home is clearly the safest option.

But there is a downside. Before widespread vote-by-mail, most Colorado voters went to a physical location to cast their ballot. If their identity was challenged because of a bad signature, they had a chance to fix it on the spot.

Now, the election process is happening inside people’s homes, out of view of elections officials and mistakes are leading tens of thousand...s of mail ballots to be rejected, uncured by the voter, and subsequently uncounted. “

Colorado Public Radio

item.title: "The first part of the movie features former extremists...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The first part of the movie features former extremists telling their story. And then in the middle, you focus on people who would have been folks these extremists would have victimized. Why did you want to set it up that way?
What I felt was missing was a section about how horrible it feels to be the victim of prejudice. I didn’t want to forget about the victims. So I interviewed some people from marginalized groups, including three from Colorado: State Representative Leslie Herod, [Colorado Muslim Leadership Council member] Nadeen Ibrahim, and Nicole Garcia, [the first transgender person and person of color to serve as a minister the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America]."

5280 Magazine
